stem: A 5-year-old child with sickle cell disease (HbSS) is brought to the ED for 'pale skin' and extreme weakness. Based on the documentation in the SCD Pediatric Emergency & Hematologic Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute life-threatening anemic crisis.
Background: History of HbSS. Usually manages pain at home.
Assessment: Child is thready and pale. The mother says, 'His stomach just got hard and big today.'
Recommendation: Immediate fluid and blood resuscitation.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 62/34, HR 162, RR 34, T 98.2Â°F. SpO2 91% on RA.

actionOptions.text: Administer STAT IV fluids (0.9% NS) and prepare for a blood transfusion
Measure the child's abdominal girth and palpate the spleen gently
Applying heat packs to the abdomen to relax the spleen
Initiate broad-spectrum antiviral therapy with Acyclovir

parameterOptions.text: Serial Hemoglobin levels and abdominal girth measurement
Heart rate and blood pressure (Signs of hypovolemic shock)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is a classic and life-threatening Acute Splenic Sequestration crisis (c2). In this condition, a large volume of the client's blood becomes 'trapped' in the spleen, leading to a sudden drop in Hgb (from 8.4 to 3.8) and hypovolemic shock (BP 62/34). Priority actions are immediate fluid and blood volume replacement (a1) and tracking the splenomegaly via abdominal girth (a2). Key parameters include the Hgb level/girth (p1) and markers of shock perfusion (p2).
clinicalPearls: Splenic sequestration can cause death in minutes to hours due to cardiovascular collapse.
The child's body is effectively 'bleeding' into their own spleen.
Emergency splenectomy may be required if the sequestration recurs.

questionTrap.trap: Calling this an 'Aplastic Crisis' because the Hgb is low.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In Aplastic crisis, the reticulocyte count is LOW (the marrow stopped working). In Sequestration, the reticulocyte count is HIGH (the marrow is trying to help, but the blood is getting trapped). Also, sequestration has splenomegaly; aplastic does not.

mnemonic.title: Spleen Trap
mnemonic.expansion: S-Sudden drop in Hgb. P-Pale skin. L-Lower BP. E-Enlarged Spleen. E-Emergency fluids. N-Nervous heart (Tachycardia).
